title: How to Make Gluten‐Free Cream Puffs

steps.headline: Make the dough.
steps.description: Heat a heavy saucepan over medium-high heat. Then place one cup of milk, one stick of butter, and a pinch of salt in a heavy saucepan. Once the butter and water has started to simmer, add the gluten-free pastry flour. Stir the mixture until it forms a thick dough. Then remove it from the heat and allow the dough to cool for about three minutes. This recipe will make about 20 puffs. You can also make your own gluten-free pastry flour blend by mixing together three cups (435 g) of white rice flour, 1 ½ cups (187 g) of tapioca, ¾ cup (123 g) of potato starch, one tablespoon (8 g) of xantham, and 1 ½ teaspoons (5 g) of salt.

steps.headline: Mix the dough.
steps.description: Once the dough is no longer hot to the touch, transfer half of it to a blender or food processor. Pulse the dough about 20 times. Then beat the eggs and slowly pour them into the food processor. Finally, add the remaining dough and pulse the mixture until it is smooth and uniform. You can also mix the dough in a standing mixer or with a hand mixer if you do not have a food processor.

steps.headline: Pour the pastries.
steps.description: Transfer the dough to a pastry bag that is fitted with a large plain tip. Then squirt about 20 small mounds of dough, roughly 1 ½ inches (3.81 cm) high, onto a greased baking tray or piece of parchment paper. Try to leave at least an inch (2.54 cm) between each pastry. To keep the tops from burning, you might wet your finger and smooth down the tops of each pastry before you put them in the oven. You can also use ice cream scoops to get more uniform-sized puffs.

steps.headline: Bake the pastries.
steps.description: While you are preparing the dough, preheat the oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190.56 degrees Celsius). Once the pastries are ready, place them in your oven on the center rack. Bake the pastries for about 10 minutes or until they are golden brown. Once they are done baking, slice a small slit in the side of the pastry to allow moisture to escape and let them cool. You can remove the pastries from the oven to let them cool or you can turn off the oven and leave the pastries in it to cool very gradually.

steps.headline: Whip the cream.
steps.description: Pour the cream into a large metal bowl. You can also pour it into the bowl of your standing mixer if you have one. Attach a whisk attachment to your mixer and whip the cream at medium speed until soft peaks begin to form in the cream.

steps.headline: Add sugar and salt.
steps.description: Once the cream begins to thicken a little, add the confectioner’s sugar and the salt. Continue to beat the cream on medium until the mixture begins to solidify. You should stop beating it if the whipped cream loses its glossiness and starts to look a little dry.

steps.headline: Mix in other flavorings.
steps.description: If you want, you can mix in other ingredients with the salt and confectioner’s sugar to add some extra flavor to your puffs. For example, you can add two tablespoons (29.57 ml) of vanilla or two tablespoons (16 g) of baking cocoa. If plain whipped cream is not satisfying enough, experiment with different flavors.

steps.headline: Slice open the pastries.
steps.description: After the pastries are cool and dry, slice them open horizontally. Depending on the puffiness of your pastry, you should have some large open space in the puff. If there is not as much room as you would like for whipped cream, you can also use your hands to remove some of the inside of the puff.

steps.headline: Pour in whipped cream.
steps.description: Once you have opened your pastry, use an ice cream scoop, spoon, or a pastry bag to fill the puff with cream. You can add as little or as much filling as you would like. However, try to keep it from running over the sides of the pastry. You want a light and fluffy treat, not a giant ball of whipped cream with some pastry in it somewhere. If you cut off the tops of the pastry, place them on top of the cream filling.

steps.headline: Top the pastry.
steps.description: After you assemble the pastry, you can top it with a number of different sweets. For example, you could sprinkle on some confectioner’s sugar, drizzle some chocolate syrup, or add a dollop of strawberry jelly. However, if you decide to flavor the whipped cream, make sure that your topping complements it. For example, a chocolate topping would go great with a plain vanilla or a chocolate flavored whipped cream filling. Avoid sprinkling the confectioner’s sugar until you are ready to serve the puffs.

steps.headline: Store the pastries.
steps.description: Once you have filled your puffs, they need to be stored in the refrigerator. This keeps the whipped cream from liquefying and spoiling. You can store the finished puffs in an airtight container for two to three days, or keep them in the freezer for several weeks. To avoid a runny filling, consider baking the pastry ahead of time and then making the filling before you serve the puffs.
